takes place at my own institution so your story too in 2010 I visited course
designed to teach digital literacy skills to college freshmen those being held in three rooms one offered a live
faculty member pacing the stage while the other rooms presented a broadcast version of her performance it
was a required general education course that focused on teaching Alice an object-oriented computer programming
language designed for k-12 students with a simple graphical user interface I was
skeptical about whether alice was the right programming language to teach college students but I knew that the
lecturing faculty member had a good reputation for innovative teaching and deploying student-centered learning
techniques so I was coming to class with an open mind at the beginning of the
quarter students in all three rooms had purchased wireless handheld clickers that could monitor their class
attendance and assure their attention did not wander too far from the subject matter during class time and hopefully
measure their performance at reaching the courses stated learning goals during
my visit to the class I soon notice the students perked up each time the screen
displayed multiple-choice questions about computer programming techniques only because they had to select the best
answer quickly among several plausible choices as a digital clock counted down
not all of the questions on the screen were straightforward problem solving
tasks about choosing the right line of code or the right order on the right operation sometimes the questions
involve fundamental definitions or more abstract reasoning about why to choose a particular approach to encourage
collaborative learning students could also periodically confer with each other in small groups and debate the merits of
the different answers in the clicker room with the live performance by the professor I watched about 45 minutes of
a college instructor trying to do everything right in addition to clicker quizzes and small group discussions she
encouraged active learning by soliciting questions and comments from students using a microphone despite her best
efforts about half the students in a lecture hall were partially engaged they
only paid attention during the quiz portions of the session much of the time these students seem to be considerably
more interested in non class related activities on laptops and cell phones that involve games and social network
sites the other half behaved more attentively like students who could see the professor and be seen occasionally there
were small dramas in a lecture hall when a student could not get his or her clicker to function and there would be a

in before the ticking clock ran out of time I then went to a large lecture hall

one was at the podium of this lecture hall the faculty lecture appeared only

students applied makeup talked on cell phones and held conversations at regular
